headline: MSCI, SemiLEDS: Biggest Price Decliners (MSCI, LEDS)

headline: Microsoft, SPDR Trust: Money Flow Leaders (MSFT, SPY)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Mosque Rally in New Delhi
summary: Many rallied in New Delhi on Wednesday against the demolition of a mosque that authorities claim had been built illegally. Some snapshots.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for Jan. 13, 2011

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Government to Intervene to Cool India Food Prices
summary: prices.

headline: Argentine President's Staffer Robbed Ahead of Middle East Trip
summary: A member of Argentine President Cristina Fernandez's staff was robbed while taking a bundle of cash to his home in the city's trendy Palermo Soho neighborhood.

headline: Private Properties
summary: Carmel Partners founder Ron Zeff lists in San Francisco and Jeff Moorad, vice chairman and chief executive of baseball's San Diego Padres, lists in Arizona's Paradise Valley. Also, former John Hancock CEO Jim Benson lists a home near Boston for $21 million.

headline: Homes with Hot Tubs
summary: Tour homes in St. George's, Grenada, San Diego and Scottsdale Ariz., all with hot tubs.

headline: Shopping Online for Great Works of Art
summary: Cindy Sherman, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Jackson Pollock and others are among the artists whose work will be featured in this month's VIP Art Fair, an entirely virtual art-world gathering that brings together work from nearly 140 galleries around the world. New websites are promoting big-name artists and emerging talents online, some set at lower prices to draw emerging collectors. Here is a sampling of some of what's for sale, and what's been selling well.

headline: TARP Inspector: Citi Remains 'Too Big to Fail'
summary: The government's 2008 rescue of Citi group encouraged the kind of risky behavior that contributed to the financial crisis and leaves standing a financial institution that remains "too big to fail," a federal watchdog said.

headline: Materials, Merck Lead Stock Decline
summary: Major stock indexes declined as materials shares lagged in the wake of disappointing economic data. A drop in Merck weighed on the Dow industrials.

headline: Options Traders Target Merck
summary: Showing trepidation about Merck's stock, traders sought new options positions after the drug company said researchers had halted one major study of an anticlotting drug and made significant changes to another.

headline: Fosun Starts Investment Fund with Prudential Financial
summary: Fosun International's $600 million joint investment fund with Prudential Financial of the U.S. is the latest move by one of China's biggest privately owned conglomerates to become more like Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.

headline: Life Partners Uses Law Firm With Close Ties to Hold Client Funds
summary: Hundreds of millions of dollars held in escrow for clients of Life Partners, a firm that buys and sells life-insurance policies for investors, are being looked after by a small law firm with limited insurance experience and close ties to the company. Legal experts say the arrangement is unusual but not improper.

headline: FDA Puts Restrictions on Acetaminophen
summary: Federal health regulators are restricting the amount of acetaminophen in prescription painkillers such as Vicodin because of concerns about liver damage.

headline: Mining Fatalities More Than Double
summary: The number of miners who died on the job more than doubled in 2010, with 29 of the fatalities occurring at Massey's Upper Big Branch mine in April.

headline: Venues for Discreet Meets
summary: Finding the right location for a bit of blue-sky thinking, not too close to the office and not so far away that it's tricky to reach can seem a difficult task, but it's far from impossible

headline: An Uncrowded Lunch at Prune
summary: Dinner and brunch at Prune in the East Village may be packed elbow to elbow, but lunch proves to be a fine time for a lovely, casual meal.

headline: FiDi's Residential Resurgence
summary: Many of Financial District's luxury condominiums, hit hard by the economic downturn, have sat half-empty or unfinished for long stretches. Now they are making a comeback.

headline: Marathon Oil Sets Spinoff
summary: Marathon Oil has revived plans to spin off the company's refining and sales operations.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Top DOJ National Security Official to Leave
summary: The Justice Department said its top national-security prosecutor, David Kris, plans to resign to join a privately held technology investment firm.

headline: Wall Street Pay Likely to Go Up
summary: Total compensation expenses for three of Wall Street's biggest investment banks in 2010 will be flat to up as much as 10%, analysts believe, though per-employee payout numbers may be lower due to higher headcounts from a year ago.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Jan. 7 amounted to 27.7% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 2.21 billion shares, or 610.0 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Thursday's pictures, President Obama offers a hug for support, men play cards in Spain, floods menace Belgium, Germany and Brazil and more.

headline: Fed Buying Gives Treasurys a Lift
summary: Treasurys rose, breaking a two-day losing streak, as the market was lifted by a bout of buying from the Federal Reserve.

headline: I'm So Sad About All  Those Pesky Acronyms
summary: Condemnation of acronyms is far from a new phenomenon ("Congress Finds, in Passing Bills, That Names Can Never Hurt You," page one, Jan. 12). Language gurus such as H.L. Mencken long ago excoriated the device. But acronyms have the advantage of brevity.

headline: Bailouts Are Failing, Slovak Finance Minister Says
summary: The top finance official of Slovakia said that efforts to defend Europe's common currency by bailing out indebted countries are failing and that financial stresses could increase over the next two years.

headline: Crude Takes Pause From Rally
summary: Crude futures settled lower after posting gains for three straight days as traders brushed off a weakening dollar and concerns faded about oil supply disruptions.

headline: Commerzbank to Raise Capital
summary: German bank Commerzbank said it will raise up to €650 million in new capital by exchanging hybrid bonds for new shares, resulting in a capital gain and an increase to its core Tier 1 ratio.

headline: Lehman Boosts Recovery View
summary: Lehman Brothers increased its estimate of how much its creditors will recover to $60.1 billion and expects to file a new plan to disperse its assets.

headline: J.P. Morgan Results to Highlight Tough Trading
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase will likely highlight a tough quarter for one of Wall Street's main profit engines when the giant bank reports fourth-quarter results on Friday, analysts said this week.

headline: Treasury to Sell $70 Billion in Debt
summary: The offerings comprise $57 billion in short-term bills and $13 billion in 10-year Treasury inflation-protected securities.

headline: Renault Files Complaint in Electric-Car Spy Case
summary: Renault filed a"complaint against persons unknown" for industrial espionage and other acts, but declined to give further details on the high-profile spying case at its electric vehicle program.

headline: China Loosens Yuan's Overseas Limits
summary: China launched a pilot program to allow domestic companies to use the yuan to invest overseas, an expansion of its efforts to foster the yuan as a major global currency.

headline: Iconic Hotel Headed for Foreclosure
summary: A Florida judge dismissed a bankruptcy proceeding dashing any hopes for a quick reopening of the iconic property of Detroit's Hotel Pontchartrain.

headline: Tesco's Holiday Sales Stumble
summary: Tesco became the latest U.K. retailer to blame poor holiday sales on heavy snows, although its international business continued to grow strongly.

headline: Ship Carrying Acid Capsizes in Rhine
summary: A tanker loaded with sulfuric acid capsized early Thursday on the Rhine river in Germany and two crew members were missing, authorities said.

headline: Gold Prices Inch Higher
summary: Gold futures finished near steady as worries about European debt eased and market participants re-evaluated a jump in U.S. unemployment claims.

headline: Lebanon Government Toppled
summary: The militant political group Hezbollah and its allies forced the collapse of Lebanon's government while its prime minister sat in the White House, dealing a blow to Washington in its battle with Iran and Syria for influence in the Mideast.

headline: Inmet, Lundin Merger Would Forge Copper Giant
summary: Inmet Mining's planned merger with Lundin Mining will create a company that is among the world's biggest copper producers as demand for the widely used industrial metal shows no signs of easing.

headline: Locke Calls for China to Open Its Markets
summary: Commerce Secretary Gary Locke called for China to follow through on its pledges to open up its market to foreign firms, seeking to ensure that next week's state visit by Chinese President Hu Jintao leads to lasting results.

headline: IPO Calendar Filling Up for Final Week of January
summary: The U.S. IPO market will reopen in the final week of January, with six deals lined up so far, including a $1.6 billion offering from consumer behavior tracker Nielsen Holdings.

headline: New Jersey Sits Out ObamaCare Fight
summary: Gov. Chris Christie says the state will abstain from the historic constitutional challenge.

headline: Jerry Brown's Budget Gambit
summary: The California governor has released his proposal to close the state's $25 billion budget gap, which includes a five-year extension of "temporary" tax hikes.

headline: Merrill, Former Leaders Paying to Settle Suit
summary: Bank of America's Merrill Lynch unit and two former top executives will pay $4.25 million to settle a lawsuit by New York state's largest pension fund over Merrill Lynch's role in the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Ireland's Cowen Refuses to Resign
summary: Ireland's Prime Minister Brian Cowen told his party that he would not resign, despite widespread pressure following revelations about his relationship with officials from the Anglo Irish Bank Corp.

headline: Judge Approves Madoff Settlement
summary: A judge signed off on a settlement in which the widow of a longtime investor with convicted Ponzi scheme operator Bernard Madoff will return $7.2 billion to the victims of the fraud.

headline: Key Brazil Industries Withstand Storms
summary: Brazilian steel and oil producers near the rain-ravaged mountainous area of Rio de Janeiro state said their operations were unaffected by the landslides and floods that have killed more than 340 people.

headline: Dell Combines Large-Enterprise, Public Units
summary: Dell plans to combine its public and large-enterprise business units to enhance its position as an information-technology provider.

headline: Stocks in Spain Continue Surge
summary: Spanish stocks surged again, led by gains for banks after a successful government-bond auction, while other European markets finished lower.

headline: Spanish Stocks Surge
summary: Spanish stocks extended their gains, led by a rise in banks after a successful government bond auction, while other European markets finished lower.

headline: First BanCorp (Puerto Rico), Golfsmith International Holdings: Biggest Price Gainers (FBP, GOLF)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Lib Dem Lawmaker Warns of 'Toughest Year' for Party
summary: Facing an expected by-election defeat and languishing in the opinion polls, senior U.K. Liberal Democrat lawmaker David Laws said colleagues are braced for their "toughest year" in 2011.

headline: Strong Demand at Europe Debt Auctions
summary: Spain, Italy and Hungary all carried out successful bond auctions, as investors showed strong demand for the bonds following Portugal's better-than-expected bond auction on Wednesday.

headline: SEC Drops Suit Against Alleged Madoff Feeder Chais
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission has dropped its lawsuit against Stanley Chais, a late Los Angeles money manager who allegedly served as one of the biggest feeders of investor funds to convicted Ponzi scheme operator Bernard Madoff.

headline: India's Political Elites Close Ranks
summary: Publicly funded polls will help incumbents stay in power.

headline: Euro Zone News Boosts Asia Markets
summary: Most Asian markets rose Thursday, cheering a temporary reprieve from European debt woes after a successful Portuguese bond sale. Australian stocks rallied as floods peaked in Queensland state.

headline: Ethiopia's Consumer Class
summary: In Ethiopia, stutter steps into the global economy have spurred change. See related article.

headline: U.K. Retailers' Fading New Year Hopes
summary: The snow turned out not to be too troublesome for U.K. retailers. Austerity measures, the prospect of rising interest rates and higher fuel prices are likely to be more of a problem for consumers spending.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields rose, but a better-than-expected auction of 30-year bonds signalled firm underlying demand.

headline: Bank of England Stays Course
summary: The BOE kept its key interest rate at a record low but pressure is growing on the central bank to respond to building price risks.

headline: Pet Franchise Seeks New Customer: The Cat Owner
summary: DoodyCalls, a waste-removal franchisor, is looking to scoop up new business by targeting feline lovers.

headline: Into the Closet
summary: Barbara Savage-Schiller of Los Angeles spent $75,000 to convert an extra bedroom into this 350-square-foot closet in 2009. See the closet's amenities, including wall-to-wall displays of her 520 pairs of shoes, a silver ottoman, and a rotating spiral rack.

headline: Deluge Threatens Iron-Ore Mining Heartland
summary: The deluge inundating Australia's Queensland state could be just the beginning of a record wet season for the country, with forecasters warning Thursday that bad weather is likely to spread to the ore-rich Pilbara region.

headline: Crucell Restarts Korean Vaccine Plant
summary: Dutch biotechnology company Crucell said it has resumed operations at its South Korean vaccines plant after shutting down the facility last year due to sterility issues.

headline: Tax Refunds Move to Debit Cards
summary: The U.S. Treasury Department plans to launch a pilot program Thursday to deliver tax refunds through prepaid debit cards, an effort to cut the expense of paper checks and aid lower-income taxpayers who don't have bank accounts.

headline: Posco Profit Falls 59%
summary: Posco, the world's third-biggest steelmaker, said fourth-quarter net profit fell 59%, weighed down by higher raw-material costs.

headline: Japan PM to Reshuffle Cabinet
summary: Japan's prime minister Naoto Kan will reshuffle his cabinet on Friday, a move aimed at placating opposition parties and boosting his flagging support ratings.

headline: Small Businesses May Be Growing Again
summary: It's no wonder the recovery has been so anemic, writes MarketWatch columnist Rex Nutting: The U.S. economy has been trying to run on one leg.

headline: MSCI 4Q Profit Up 23%
summary: MSCI's fiscal fourth-quarter profit increased 23% on a bigger-than-expected rise in revenue, though costs from the market indexing firm's past acquisitions cut into its margins.

headline: Gates Seeks to Placate in Tokyo
summary: U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates attempted to reduce pressure on the government to move quickly on relocating a U.S. military base on Okinawa, instead focusing his discussions on the threat from North Korea.

headline: Cnooc Plans Bond Offering
summary: China's Cnooc plans to issue international bonds to institutional investors, becoming the latest Chinese company to tap the offshore bond market amid tightening liquidity at home.

headline: GE to Buy Lineage Power
summary: General Electric agreed to buy Lineage Power from private-equity firm Gores Group for $520 million, giving GE entry to the power-conversion market.

headline: EPA Grants Greenhouse-Gas Rule Exemption
summary: The EPA is granting an exemption under its controversial greenhouse-gas requirements, saying that it will provide a three-year reprieve for facilities that burn wood chips and other biomass products to generate electricity.

headline: Housing Bust Hits Banesto
summary: Spanish lender Banco Español de Crédito reported weak fourth-quarter results, as it took further steps to clean up its loan book in the wake of a massive housing bust.

headline: Metals Prices to Boost Anglo Platinum
summary: Anglo Platinum, the world's largest producer of the metal, said it expects its 2010 earnings roughly tripled due to a jump in the price received for platinum-group metals.

headline: Talk to Chuck? Better Bring Your Galoshes
summary: Charles Schwab Corp.'s handling of the YieldPlus fiasco undermines the company's biggest strength: the trust it has built with clients.

headline: Total in Talks on U.K. Refinery
summary: France's Total is currently in discussions with a preferred bidder to sell its U.K.-based refinery in Lindsey, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Tata Steel Sets Date for Share Offering
summary: Tata Steel plans to launch its proposed $813 million follow-on public share offering on Jan. 19, according to people involved in the transaction.

headline: Irish Regulator Probing Banks
summary: The chief executive of Ireland's National Asset Management Agency said that the financial regulator is probing information provided by banks relating to overly positive loan-to-value ratios banks gave to the agency prior to transferring loans.

headline: American Assets Trust IPO Prices Near Top of Range
summary: The San Diego commercial landlord kicked off this year's IPO market for real estate investment trusts by raising $563.75 million.

headline: Fast Retailing Profit Drops 35%
summary: Fast Retailing, which own the Uniqlo retail chain, saw quarterly net profit fall 35% following weak sales of autumn and winter clothing due to unseasonably high temperatures.

headline: U.K. Manufacturing Output Grows
summary: U.K. manufacturing output rose steadily in November, suggesting the sector helped support economic growth in the fourth quarter.

headline: Groupama Eyes Fondiaria Stake
summary: French insurer Groupama said it's interested in buying a stake of up to 20% stake in Italian insurer Fondiaria-SAI, Italy's second-largest insurer. It added, however, that it isn't seeking control of the company.

headline: Infosys Drags Down Indian Shares
summary: Indian shares closed sharply lower Thursday, dragged down by lower-than-expected earnings from Infosys Technologies and as renewed concerns over rising interest rates sparked a selloff in banking stocks.

headline: Maruti to Raise Car Prices
summary: Maruti Suzuki India said it will raise vehicle prices next week to offset higher input costs.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, an Australian floats in a fridge, a 'gorilla' takes a snow day in New York, a sea gull lands on a man's head in Germany and more.

headline: Emerging Markets Drive Peugeot
summary: PSA Peugeot Citroën said its 13% year-to-year rise in sales of new vehicles in 2010 was boosted by a surge in demand from markets outside Europe, a trend that appears to be growing.

headline: Moody's: U.K. Should Keep Triple-A Rating
summary: The U.K. government's "ambitious" program to pare back the budget deficit means the country should maintain its triple-A credit rating, Moody's Investors Service said.

headline: History of Indian Aviation
summary: IndiGo's record $15.6 billion order for 180 Airbus A320 is a sign that the Indian aviation industry is picking up again after the slump of the last couple of years.

headline: Germany Flags Afghan Drawdown
summary: The German government resolved to start withdrawing troops from Afghanistan by the end of the year and tempered expectations for the conditions it will leave behind.

headline: Currencies and Stocks Are at Odds
summary: For much of last year, the foreign-exchange market and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index were sounding alarms about future volatility in prices and exchange rates. Lately, though, forex and stock traders seem to be dancing to a different tune.

headline: Ecuador Bolsters Health Care System
summary: Facing a deteriorating infrastructure and overwhelming demand, Ecuador President Rafael Correa declared a state of emergency in the public health system this week aimed at improving care in some of the nation's largest public hospitals.

headline: World Bank: Inflows Not Cause of China Inflation
summary: China's inflation shouldn't be blamed on capital inflows, said a senior economist at the World Bank, instead attributing it to expansionary monetary and fiscal policies as well as surging food prices.

headline: Sun Holdings Seeks $1 Billion IPO
summary: Sun Holdings plans to raise at least $1 billion in an IPO ahead of a Hong Kong listing.

headline: Japan as a Standard Bearer
summary: The push to make Japan's manufacturers the standard setters is a plank in the government's effort to bolster infrastructure exports and increase revenue from intellectual property. On this front, Japan lags industrial rivals, and faces an emerging challenge from China.

headline: A Gold Coast Party Pad
summary: When Karen and Roger Cartwright became empty nesters in the late 1990s, they decided to reinvent themselves: They wanted to build a dream house where, said Ms. Cartwright, "we could throw lavish parties like the ones we heard about in Hugh Hefner's Playboy mansion."

headline: Australians Face Higher Grocery Bills From Floods
summary: The flooding in Australia's Queensland state has devastated the region's agricultural heartland which could result in shortages of some fruits and vegetables and higher grocery bills for Australians in coming months.

headline: India Celebrates Lohri
summary: India celebrates the Punjabi festival of Lohri, which marks the end of the winter. It's also a celebration of fire. Some snapshots of the preparations ahead of the celebrations.

headline: Tesla Expects $60 Million From RAV4
summary: Tesla Motors expects to get about $60 million in revenue from building the electric guts of an upcoming Toyota RAV4 sport-utility vehicle.

headline: After China, Gates Goes to Rally Japan
summary: The U.S. defense secretary is expected to push Tokyo to involve itself more in the region's defense to ease tension on the Korean peninsula and counterbalance China's military buildup.

headline: Portugal's Bond Sale Sets Off a Rally
summary: European stock markets rallied broadly after a successful Portuguese bond auction allayed near-term fears about the spread of the euro-zone debt crisis.

headline: Euro Gains Broadly
summary: The euro jumped more than 1% against the dollar, after a slightly stronger-than-expected debt auction in Portugal ignited a rebound in New York trading.

headline: Shanghai Loosens Private-Equity Rules
summary: China's commercial center, Shanghai, will make it easier for foreigners to invest in the private-equity sector, a move that could give the nascent homegrown industry a boost.

headline: Queensland Gets Gas Boost
summary: As the economic losses from Australia's devastating floods mounted, Queensland state was boosted Thursday after energy companies gave final approval to a US$16 billion liquefied natural gas venture.

headline: News Corp. Explores Myspace Strategic Options
summary: Myspace's CEO told employees that parent News Corp. is exploring a sale, merger or spinoff of the social-media website, one day after laying off half Myspace's work force.

headline: Stocks Rally After Portugal Auction
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished higher by 83.56 points, or 0.72%, at 11755.44 as Portugal's successful debt auction eased some euro-zone worries.

headline: Canadian Copper Miners Inmet, Lundin to Merge
summary: Canadian copper miners Inmet Mining Corp. and Lundin Mining Corp. said Wednesday they would combine in a merger of equals worth about C$9 billion in stock.

headline: FBI Seeks Suspect's Web-Game Records
summary: The FBI asked an Internet game administrator to hand over records of messages by Loughner, following a WSJ article describing disturbing messages he wrote.

headline: Concerns Linger Over Portugal
summary: Portugal passed a key test by carrying out a pair of government-bond auctions, but the high interest rates demanded by investors on the new debt sustained concerns that the Iberian country could be next in line for a bailout.

headline: AIG Plans Sale of Taiwan Unit
summary: American International Group has agreed to sell its Taiwan unit to a dark-horse bidder for $2.16 billion in its second attempt to exit the market.

headline: House Pays Tribute to Shooting Victims
summary: The House of Representatives, shaken by an attack on one of its members, put partisanship aside to honor victims of the shooting spree outside a Tucson, Ariz., supermarket.

headline: Audits Add Shine to Firms
summary: Small businesses whose books are audited by a hired certified public accountant improve their chances of getting a loan than businesses with less scrutinized financial statements.

headline: Food and Oil Drive Up Import Prices
summary: U.S. import prices extended their recent climb in December, rising 1.1% from a month on the back of resurgent energy costs.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Jan. 13, 2011

headline: Andrew Kohut: Friend or Foe? How Americans See China
summary: For the first time, the public thinks Asia is more vital to U.S. interests than Europe.

headline: Arthur B. Laffer: A Price for Raising the Debt Ceiling
summary: Republicans should attach provisions repealing the worst aspects of ObamaCare and financial reform to spending that the president absolutely needs.

headline: Fuel-Economy Rules Worry Car Makers
summary: Auto makers are asking newly empowered House Republicans to help fight a proposal under consideration by the Obama administration to boost fuel-economy standards for new cars and trucks to as high as 62 miles per gallon by 2025.

headline: Cashman Doesn't Expect Pettitte Back
summary: The Jets on Wednesday placed right tackle Damien Woody on season-ending injured reserve after he sustained an injury to his left Achilles' tendon in Saturday's win over the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: FDIC Set to Weigh Pay Revamp, Liquidation Authority
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. plans next week to consider how to discourage executive-pay practices that spur too much risk taking, as well regulations that start the process of giving the government power to seize and dismantle large, troubled financial firms.

headline: Tom Brady Is Hogging All the Superlatives
summary: After three Super Bowl rings, one NFL MVP trophy and six Pro Bowl trips, Tom Brady is in the midst of his most impressive, most dominating, definitely most finger-pointing-worthy season.

headline: Free-Floating Yuan Coming, but Slowly
summary: The yuan has a long way to go before it is fully convertible in international markets, but Bank of China's move to permit U.S.-based trading is a significant development in what is seen as its inexorable march toward that status.

headline: Volvo Mulls China-Made Cars for U.S.
summary: The new China-based owners of Volvo and the Swedish car maker's management are considering exporting Volvos assembled in China to the U.S.—a move that might harm the brand's Scandinavian identity and could make it among the first to bring China-made vehicles to the U.S.

headline: Death Toll in Mexico's Drug War Hits Record
summary: The drug-related death toll in Mexico climbed to 15,273 in 2010, the highest casualty rate since the government launched an assault on powerful cartels in 2006, Mexican officials said.

headline: Banking Law Hung Up On Down Payments
summary: Banks are sparring over looming U.S. mortgage-lending rules that could hike costs for millions of borrowers as regulators race to meet an April deadline for issuing the regulations.

headline: Joseph Sternberg: China's Risky Rare-Earth Gamble
summary: Beijing is poorly situated to win whatever game it's playing with resource supplies.

headline: City Plows Through the Storm
summary: New Yorkers unleashed a torrent of rage two weeks ago when they didn't see any plows and large swaths of the city were buried in snow. On Wednesday, they complained they couldn't sleep because there were too many plows making too much noise.

headline: Health-Law Repeal Hardly a Panacea for CEOs' Concerns
summary: Republicans want to repeal the Obama health law, a symbol of all that they—and many voters—dislike about President Obama and congressional Democrats' approach to governing. If you were a business executive and employer, would you really favor repeal?

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Columnist Michael Medved on the dustup between Sarah Palin and Charles Krauthammer.

headline: Football's Chattiest Announcers
summary: Which set of announcers is most likely to give you a headache? We studied every major NFL announcing team and counted how many words-per-minute the play-by-play and color men said.

headline: Don't Bank on Hedge-Fund Gold Rush
summary: Hedge-fund start-ups in 2010 reached the highest level since the boom. But would-be hedge-fund tycoons shouldn't get their hopes up.

headline: Banks' Housing Giveaway
summary: Buy a foreclosed home, get a TV? It is no joke. Banks' holdings of distressed properties remain a burden, even with foreclosure activity slowing since the fall.

headline: Waxing Poetic
summary: I despair for the future of the physical book, but apparently not as much as Veronika Teuber. The German-born artist spends her days on the Lower East Side preserving her library in beeswax.

headline: Portland Prairie Craftsman
summary: Attracted by the inlaid hardwood and leaded glass doors, the owners of this 87-year-old home in a Portland suburb updated the house with a new heating/cooling system, paint and carpets, but left all the original architectural details.

headline: ICE Trust Was Properly Put on Hold
summary: Regarding your editorial "Derivatives Rules on ICE" (Jan. 7):  ICE Trust's proposed risk structure was unsound. ICE's application failed to properly disperse its risk over several, diversified and non correlated clearing members

headline: Morality Is Involved  In Honoring Contracts
summary: James Garton's claim that "morality has nothing to do" with a borrower's strategic default of a mortgage obligation (Banks and Borrowers Should Have No Gripe, Letters, Jan. 8) is most troubling. My mortgage note says that "I . . . promise to pay."

headline: SABMiller Taps Ethiopia's 'Holy Water'
summary: Water seeping from fissures of volcanic rock in Ambo, Ethiopia, was prized by the nation's last emperor and residents for its restorative powers. Today, Ambo water is bottled and sold by SABMiller around the world.

headline: When 'Veteran' Is An Understatement
summary: If Dave Eichelberger makes the cut at this week's Sony Open, he'll become the oldest player ever to do so on the PGA Tour. Plus, why a close game between Baltimore and Pittsburgh seems virtually assured.

headline: Rove: Why Obama Chose Bill Daley
summary: The departure of press secretary Robert Gibbs is another sign that big White House changes are afoot.

headline: A Continent of New Consumers Beckons
summary: There's a new gold rush under way for Africa's emerging middle class, with people beginning to embrace cellphone texting and supermarket trips. But there's still a long way to go before Africa becomes the next Asia.

headline: Beach Community Divided by a Line
summary: The proposal to erect an eruv is roiling Westhampton Beach and nearby communities where the religious boundary would extend.

headline: Seeking Women, Davos Tries Quotas
summary: The World Economic Forum said it has introduced a quota for female executives from major sponsors at its Davos summit, following criticism that not enough women attend the gathering of global business leaders.

headline: Kindle vs. iPad for E-Books
summary: Technology columnist Walter S. Mossberg answers a reader's question about the Kindle as an alternative to the iPad.

headline: The Cost of Living
summary: In "The Price of Everything," Eduardo Porter applies an economic model to all sorts of life choices, social structures and cultural trends—animal rights, monogamy, religion and a great deal more. Jonathan V. Last reviews.

headline: Zipping Bad Vibes in Foreclosed Homes
summary: The foreclosure crisis has resurrected an ancient tradition: the ritual house cleansing. Buyers are consulting witches, psychics and priests to bless homes that suffer from "bad energy" associated with money problems.
